dataQualityDesignMitigationQ1: Documented processes will be in place to test datasets against biases and other unexpected outcomes.
dataQualityDesignMitigationQ2: This information will be made publicly available.
dataQualityDesignMitigationQ3: Documentation showing how data quality issues have been resolved during the design process will be developed.
dataQualityDesignMitigationQ4: This information will be made publicly available.
dataQualityDesignMitigationQ5: A Gender Based Analysis will be done against the data used by the system.
dataQualityDesignMitigationQ6: This information will be made publicly available.
dataQualityDesignMitigationQ7: Accountability for the design, development, maintenance and improvement of the system will be assigned.
dataQualityDesignMitigationQ8: Documented processes will be in place to manage the risk that outdated or unreliable data will be used by the system.
dataQualityDesignMitigationQ9: This information will be made publicly available.
dataQualityDesignMitigationQ10: All of the data used by the system will be posted on the Open Government Portal.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ1: The audit trail will identify the authority or delegated authority identified in legislation.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ2: The system will provide an audit trail that records all of the recommendations or decisions made by the system.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ3: Key decision points will be identifiable in the audit trail.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ4: All key decision points will be linked to relevant legislation, policies and procedures.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ5: A log will be kept detailing all of the changes made to the model and to the system.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ6: An audit trail that clearly sets out all of the decision points made by the system will be developed.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ8: The audit trail could be used to generate a notification or statement of reasons for each decision it supports.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ7: The audit trail will identify which version of the system was used for each decision it supports.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ9: The audit trail will show who the authorized decision maker is.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ10: The system will be able to produce reasons for its decisions or recommendations when required.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ11: There will be a process in place to grant, monitor and revoke access permissions to the system.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ12: There will be a mechanism in place to capture feedback by users of the system.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ13: There will be a resource process established for clients that wish to challenge the decision.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ14: The system will enable human override of system decisions.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ15: There will be a process to log the instances when overrides were performed.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ16: The audit trail will include change control processes to record modifications to the system's operation or performance.
proceduralFairnessDesignMitigationQ17: A concept case will be developed and presented to the Government of Canada's Enterprise Architecture Review Board.
privacyDesignMitigationQ1: A Privacy Impact Assessment will be undertaken, or existing PIA will be revised.
privacyDesignMitigationQ2: The system will reflect Privacy by Design principles
